qas.question: What programming languages does Windows Runtime work with?

answers.text: C, C++, Visual Basic .NET, C#, along with HTML5 and JavaScript

qas.question: What makes Windows apps binary code compatible?
What does compiling components as Windows Runtime make possible?

answers.text: permitting consumption by all compatible languages

qas.question: What kind of environment provides Windows apps extra security?

plausible_answers.text: C, C++, Visual Basic .NET, C#, along with HTML5 and JavaScript

qas.question: What programming languages does Windows Downtime work with?

plausible_answers.text: C, C++, Visual Basic .NET, C#, along with HTML5 and JavaScript

qas.question: What programming languages does Windows Runtime work without?
What makes Windows apps unary code compatible?

plausible_answers.text: permitting consumption by all compatible languages

qas.question: What does compiling components as Windows Runtime make impossible?
What kind of environment provides Windows apps less security?

context: Windows Store apps run within a new set of APIs known as Windows Runtime, which supports programming languages such as <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>C, C++, Visual Basic .NET, C#, along with HTML5 and JavaScript<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>. <a1_0>If <b6_0>written in some "high-level" languages<b6_0/><a1_0/>, apps written for Windows Runtime can be compatible with both Intel and ARM versions of Windows, otherwise they are not binary code compatible. Components may be compiled as Windows Runtime Components, <a2_0><b7_0>permitting consumption by all compatible languages<b7_0/><a2_0/>. To ensure stability and security, apps run within a <a3_0><b8_0>sandboxed environment<b8_0/><a3_0/>, and require permissions to access certain functionality, such as accessing the Internet or a camera.
